perturbation.original_text: Nothing in this Agreement shall cause Subcontractor in any way to be construed as a partner or joint venture with, or an employee of, EDGE in connection with or arising from Subcontractor's rendering of Work to EDGE pursuant to this Agreement. EDGE retains Subcontractor only for the purposes and to the extent as set forth in this Agreement, and Subcontractor's relation to EDGE during the term of this Agreement shall be that of an independent contractor and nothing herein shall create or imply any other or different relationship.
perturbation.changed_text: Nothing in this Agreement shall cause Subcontractor in any way to be construed as a partner or joint venture with, or an employee of, EDGE in connection with or arising from Subcontractor's rendering of Work to EDGE pursuant to this Agreement. EDGE retains Subcontractor only for the purposes and to the extent as set forth in this Agreement, and Subcontractor's relation to EDGE during the term of this Agreement shall be that of an independent contractor. For the purposes of liability, however, Subcontractor shall be considered an employee of EDGE.
perturbation.explanation: This change creates a contradiction. The paragraph initially establishes the subcontractor as an independent contractor, but then adds a clause stating that for liability purposes, the subcontractor will be considered an employee. This contradictory statement creates legal uncertainty about the subcontractor's true status.
perturbation.contradicted_law: IRS guidelines on determining worker classification (employee vs. independent contractor)
perturbation.law_explanation: The modified text contradicts IRS guidelines, which emphasize behavioral control, financial control, and the relationship of the parties to determine worker classification. The contradiction between 'independent contractor' and 'employee for liability' introduces ambiguity, potentially leading to misclassification under tax law and liability disputes. An official IRS document on independent contractor status is included as the second link.

perturbation.original_text: EDGE and Subcontractor shall not be obligated to resolve by arbitration any claim or dispute related to the Agreement. It is mandatory that any controversy or claim arising out of or relating to the Agreement or the breach thereof shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the State of Texas and the venue shall be exclusively in Collin County, Texas for resolution.
perturbation.changed_text: EDGE and Subcontractor may elect to resolve by arbitration any claim or dispute related to the Agreement. Conversely, it is mandatory that any controversy or claim arising out of or relating to the Agreement or the breach thereof shall be subject to the jurisdiction of the State of Texas and the venue shall be exclusively in Collin County, Texas for resolution.
perturbation.explanation: The original text specified that arbitration was not an option. The modified text introduces arbitration as an optional method of resolution, while simultaneously stating that all disputes are MANDATORY subject to the jurisdiction of the State of Texas and Collin County. This introduces ambiguity and potential conflict.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Federal Arbitration Act (FAA) on enforceability of arbitration agreements
perturbation.law_explanation: The FAA favors the enforcement of valid arbitration agreements. By making arbitration optional while also mandating jurisdiction in Texas courts, the modification creates uncertainty about whether an arbitration agreement, if entered, would be enforceable, especially if one party prefers litigation in Texas. The simultaneous statements that arbitration can be elected, but litigation is mandatory causes confusion.

perturbation.original_text: Subcontractor shall obtain at its own cost and expense and maintain the insurance in full force and effect during the term of the Agreement as required herein. A copy of the (i) certificate(s) of insurance and (ii) endorsements, acceptable to EDGE, shall be submitted to EDGE prior to commencement of any Work and renewals or replacements of such certificates shall be so delivered at least 30 days prior to the expiration or termination of each such policy.
perturbation.changed_text: Subcontractor shall obtain at its own cost and expense insurance; however, the specific type and amount of insurance will be at EDGE's discretion. A copy of the (i) certificate(s) of insurance and (ii) endorsements, acceptable to EDGE, shall be submitted to EDGE prior to commencement of any Work and renewals or replacements of such certificates shall be so delivered at least 30 days prior to the expiration or termination of each such policy.
perturbation.explanation: This modification gives EDGE complete control over the required insurance, contradicting the initial statement that the insurance must meet certain requirements as defined elsewhere in the agreement. This creates ambiguity about what insurance coverage is actually required, and if the requirements specified later in section 9 are valid.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Texas Insurance Code provisions on required insurance coverage for contractors
perturbation.law_explanation: While the provided Texas Insurance Code section focuses on general contractor regulations, the principle of requiring contractors to maintain adequate and legally compliant insurance is fundamental. Giving EDGE arbitrary discretion over the insurance type and amount could lead to the subcontractor being underinsured or not having legally required coverage, potentially violating implied obligations and general contractor regulations. The second link gives a PDF with more information on insurance requirements.
